title: Workshop Aims & Objectives

author: Stelios Piperidis, Institute for Language and Speech Processing (ILSP / "Athena" R.C.)

segmentation: So the previous speaker, I think covered many of the things that I wanted to say.
So I mean we can.
We can save time somehow, but since there is a slide set, let me drive you through this slide set a bit more quickly than it would have been if the previous speaker.
Not covered all these topics so.
This is a picture I don't know how visible it is, but it is a picture that was taken in 2011 I think.
Actually it was September 2011.
It was not taken by from a satellite or anything like that.
It is a picture depicting the languages that people using the Twitter social media have been using to write their tweets.
So for each area you have a different color and you see this panopticon of languages, not only European languages but also other languages.
OK that people use to communicate daily.
Pretty certain that in Europe of 2015 this picture is much more colorful and much more complex if you want.
So I mean, Europe is fundamentally multilingual.
As we heard we have 24 official languages in the connecting European Facility program.
We also have two additional languages.
This is Icelandic and Norwegian.
And according to the European policy, Multilinguality is an asset.
So the fact that people speak different languages should not be seen as as a barrier, but it should be seen and should be conceived as a cultural and political asset of Europe.
However, nobody speaks all the languages and we have to make sure that the languages do not create silos or they do not create invisible borders.
Invisible barriers at a time that we all try successfully around successfully.
Depending on the challenges in the way we face these challenges to pull down all the borders amungus the mobility of people, the information, the mobility of information.
The mobility of ideas and Commerce should not be restricted by the fact that we all speak different languages.
So the question is, how do you achieve this then?
As it happens.
I think it was Umberto Eco who said that if there is one language in Europe, then this language is.
Translation so Europe's language is translation.
However, translation as a process is a very skillful demands.
Very skilled people.
It demands too much talent.
It is very.
Difficult at times.
Most of most of the times, especially when high quality translation is is at stake.
However, in today's society with the Internet, with all the the tools that we have to generate content ourselves, there is a lot to translate.
In fact, there is so much that we have to translate in all the languages that I really doubt whether if we start it today.
I mean, all the translators, all the skilled translators.
We would be able to render the content in both professional content but also.
User generated content in all the other languages.
So what do you do?

You do what you do in all other cases where you need, let's say, to do something if you want more quickly somehow more efficiently, sometimes maybe sacrificing a bit of quality, but you need to serve a purpose.
OK, so you.
Somehow resort to technology you resort to technology support.
No, we all have experience and I think it has been hinted at at the previous shorter talks.
That quality is is an issue.
It is.

It is doubted whether we have already got to know the complexities of human translation, whether we have, if you want deconvoluted the signals of this highly complex cognitive process, so so far the model and the idea is that we have human translation that is supported by technology.
And this human translation that is supported by technology is what we call automated translation.
This is a convention.
If you want an Angus versus what we call machine translation, where you have a fully automatic process.
The previous speaker talked about multilingual the multilingual digital single market.
The role of the Connecting Europe facility in this.
In achieving this goal of the multilingual digital Single Market, and as it was also said, automated translation is one of the digital.
Initiatives, digital infrastructure services and initiatives that CF is supporting.
This is the safe .80 in short, for self dot automated translation.
Automated translation has been at easy for many years, so translation, memories, terminology, databases, all sorts of tools have been at the disposal of translators.
Machine translation goes loans as it was said in 2013 and this is codenamed empty at AC.
Now this neus F .8 is a bit special in the sense that although in the past the automated translation machine translation were the disposal.
Of the institution of the European institutions, now with safety, we're talking about targeting people like us.
OK, the citizens and the public sector.
Practitioners and servants in each and every Member State.
So the focus is on you.
The focus is on us said that 80 is free.
No.
Safe dot AT and empty at the C will dim and.
Data.
To be trained as we will say later on.
The modern technology heavily relies on data, and what do we mean by data?
We mean human translations, human translations, out of which the modern empty systems learn to translate now.
In the very same sense that when you have, when you're very good at translating medical texts, you have.
If you want all the knowledge, all the terminology, all the phraseology and you have a big Bank of medical translations in mind.
If you are asked to move to legal text or technology etc, you may face problems in the very same manner.
Modern machine translation, statistical machine translation, and any type of.

A translation tool will face problems, so if we want to move from the texts that empty at EC and safe and the automated translation tools of the Commission have learned to translate, then we need to feed these engines with data that are appropriate for the particular purposes that we want to use these technologies.
So your data, the data that you are going to translate.
If you want you're going to use the system for are the best are the best data.
Without this data, simply it will not work.
So that's why we're here.
We want to discuss about the value of data we want to discuss about the way data will be used in statistical machine translation and in the Safe .80 platform in general.
And as I said, at the very short welcome we're doing this in each and every country.
We're different languages spoken, so we're doing it in 30 countries, covering 26.
Languages.
Who are the key players in this elar C endeavor?
It is you the public services that ministrations the ministries, etc.
It is the European Commission, the safe, the empty at EC groups, etc.
It is the EU and the safe affiliated countries, and it is elar C and This Is Us if you want.
Semen, crack and myself are instances of elar C in this in this room and the whole story is about finding the right data.
Just one word about LRC.
The European Language resource coordination.
The oeler SQR.
Just conduits.
We do not impose anything.
We're not parachutists in any process.
We do not own anything.
Everything is owned by you by the states, OK, and by the Commission, and everything is shared between the States and the Commission.
So view Elar C as the intermediaries.
The facilitators in this process.
In each country we work with national experts that we call national anchor points.
We have two national anchor points, two types.

If you want of national anchor points, we have a technical scientific national anchor point which in your case is Simone Crack and possibly Marco Global Nick and we will also have a public national anchor point which will be a representative from the public sector and this is in coordination.
With the local government with the government of the country, it is being appointed together with I mean by the local government and the European Commission.
In the process we also have the local digital offices that play a major role and this is Peter Yaksa as the local digital officer here.
And as we said, the objective of all these.
Of all these players within Elar C is to find and share the data so that we achieve the best results for your needs and and your language.
During the workshop, we hope.
We will see, we hope that we will be able to raise awareness on the value and importance of data.
Will raise awareness of how we will use this data to adapt safe .80 for the day-to-day needs of public services in all CF related countries.
Would like to engage you and your teams, that's why I said, let's make it as informal and as interactive as possible and we will.
Shed some light on the technical and legal issues that always.
If you won't infringe.
When you talk about data sharing, especially when we talk about data sharing between governments and the Commission.
The agenda.
In the morning, we'll hear about European multilingualism by Peter Yaksha.
Then Simone Crack will shed light on language or languages.
As I heard yesterday, I didn't know that there are obligations for multilingual rendering.
If you won't.
Even in Slovenia and as Simon told me yesterday, there are certain areas where.
I mean there are more than one languages.
We're information has to be published.
This is the case in many other languages.
In many other countries in in Europe, then we will have a panel on multilingual public services in Slovenia.
After the coffee break, we will have two talks about how machine translation works today and.
An incarnation if you want off statistical machine translation, which is the empty at EC will also be presented through video conference by Spiros Pillows.
The video conference will be between I think here and Luxembourg.
Right after the lunch we will talk a bit more practically about what data we need.
We need particular types of of data and the legal framework for contributing this data and immediately after this we will have a first hand.
If you want experience of.
Of people that have used these tools one way or or or another and we will have a discussion on how these tools from the state that we they are today could be could be improved.
And we will finish with a very short presentation on technical and practical aspects.
I mean, assuming that you have a data set that you want to share today, what do you do?
I mean, the very practical steps and after a short discussion, which I hope that it will be very interactive and very fruitful, will finish hopefully around 4:30.
So with this I would like to thank you and just present you if you want with the motor that we have in this tour of Europe, around the LRC.
Supporting our languages is supporting Europe and supporting Europe is supporting our languages and not supporting out languages.
OK?
Thank you very much.
